A preview of Computational Social Science for Sustainability

news
review
Author

Matthew A. Turner

Published

November 20, 2024

Introduction

Sustainable human thriving is threatened by anthropogenic climate change and ecosystem degredation caused by human behaviors. This further inflames political and social instability and increases the risk of and uncertainty around pandemics and other catastrophes. The social substrate from which these challenges emerge is the most complex system there is. To study social dynamics and sustainability, we must reevaluate, repurpose, or recombine existing scientific methodologies to synthesize new, practical social scientific theories (Fodor 1974; Feyerabend 2010) that can help reduce risk and uncertainty to “steward[]…global collective behavior” towards more equitable, prosperous, and sustainable equilibria (Bak-Coleman et al. 2021).

In this blog post, I outline how computational social science in its current state provides a useful synthesis along these lines, along with a set of other basic ingredients which can be refined for specific problems in sustainability (Pisor, Lansing, and Magargal 2023; Currie et al. 2024). Here I begin laying out the structure and material for a new course and book I will begin teaching in January 2025 at the Stanford Doerr School of Sustainability, Computational Social Science for Sustainability.

Bak-Coleman, Joseph B., Mark Alfano, Wolfram Barfuss, Carl T. Bergstrom, Miguel A. Centeno, Iain D. Couzin, Jonathan F. Donges, et al. 2021. “Stewardship of global collective behavior.” Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America 118 (27): 1–10. https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.2025764118.
Currie, Thomas E., Monique Borgerhoff Mulder, Laurel Fogarty, Maja Schlüter, Carl Folke, L. Jamila Haider, Guido Caniglia, et al. 2024. “Integrating evolutionary theory and social-ecological systems research to address the sustainability challenges of the Anthropocene.” Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences 379 (1893). https://doi.org/10.1098/rstb.2022.0262.
Feyerabend, Paul. 2010. Against Method. 4th ed. London: Verso.
Fodor, J. A. 1974. “Special sciences (or: The disunity of science as a working hypothesis).” Synthese 28 (2): 97–115. https://doi.org/10.1007/BF00485230.
Pisor, Anne, J. Stephen Lansing, and Kate Magargal. 2023. “Climate change adaptation needs a science of culture.” Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences 378 (1889). https://doi.org/10.1098/rstb.2022.0390.
